And yet...

topics.body: What's a Mormon?

topics.body:
"@HJSDGCE":/dis/the-time-wasting-thread/post/5392c2246368726523600400#post_5392c2246368726523600400
I could be curt and just say to google it, but in short, it's a nickname for a member of the LDS church, "Mormon" because of the name of one of the set of scriptures we use called, "The Book of Mormon", which is the book that Gizoid101 is apparently reading.

topics.body:
I've been kind of busy lately; my computer died, had to get this new one, running late on school assignments, trying to get a job, trying to start up the gsa again.

I realized something kind of hilariously ironic though about how the world works;
The war economy is self destructive.  What I mean by this is that the first world countries constantly work for getting better military equipment and if not buying it from their allies; third world countries and second world countries get the scraps or have to massively suck up.

The irony of this is that several first world countries and such are working on "iron man" armour.  The reason why this is ironic is that in say twenty years all the first world countries are going to have armour for soldiers that bullets bounce off of and explosive only knock the crap out of them instead of killing them.  We have tanks that rockets literally just bounce off of; imagine soldiers having armour like that.  The reason why this is funny is think what that's going to do to war.
topics.author: 38b55cdf63616403d7560600

topics.body:
"@uc9":/dis/the-time-wasting-thread/post/53934b0563687276327c0000#post_53934b0563687276327c0000
The way innovations in warfare (usually) work is that you have a constant "one-upping" battle of those who develop weapons and those who develop means to nullify and guard against those weapons.
"Iron Man" armour would only be just another advancement in defense (as well as a bit in offense) and it wouldn't be long until someone developed a weapon that would exploit the weakness of that armour, which would then cause teams to rally and try to "patch up" those weak points and develop even stronger offensive and defensive measures.
It is a self destructive system, but if it can be sustained enough, it can go on through progression for quite a while, even where - in theory - one could build some kind of world-smashing, gravitical rail-gun that fires a single particle at ludicrous speeds in just the right trajectory and put sizable dents (if not more) into the surfaces of whole planets; and in retaliation, gravity-controlling systems to stop any incoming subatomic slugs of that nature; and even build things more powerful than that.
But technology like that would be too elusive for a faulty system of warfare like ours - we'd more than likely annihilate each other long before we could develop that kind of technology.  It'd pretty much take a miracle or several to pull us through to that point.
topics.author: 4fde0c7e945b706cc30003eb

topics.body:
"@CogWeaver":/dis/the-time-wasting-thread/post/53935158636872775b8b0200#post_53935158636872775b8b0200
I'm not saying that war will go away; rather war as we know it today.  For the past couple of decades it has been a extremely rare occurrence for first world countries to go to war directly with another first world country; most of those times have been proxy wars instead.  Most wars now are either first world countries fighting third or second world countries/second or third world countries fighting amongst themselves.

What TALOS and armour like it would do is pretty much eliminate first world countries vs second or third world countries types of wars cause at that point it's no longer a actual war so much as a game of "Eeny, meeny, miny, moe- FUCK YOU!"
!http://fc05.deviantart.net/fs71/f/2013/025/0/e/little_man_syndrome_by_jollyjack-d5sno37.jpg!
Joking aside NATO countries already have the overwhelming military force in the world; what TALOS would do is robbed underdeveloped countries of any ability to actually fight back.
